intro: Galium suberectum, commonly known as creeping bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial plant native to North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, prostrate stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Galium suberectum thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and streambanks.
